revision.text:
[[File:Blu-ray disc (BD-RE).JPG|right|thumb|200px|A blank rewritable Blu-ray Disc (BD-RE)]] {{Optical disc authoring}}
'''[[Blu-ray Disc]] Recordable''' (or '''BD-R''') refers to two [[Direct-to-disk recording|direct to disc]] [[optical disc recording technologies]] that can be recorded on to an [[optical disc]] with an [[optical disc recorder]]. '''BD-R''' discs can be written to once, whereas '''BD-RE''' ('''Blu-ray Disc Recordable Erasable''') can be erased and re-recorded multiple times. Disc capacities are 25 [[gigabyte|GB]] for single-layer discs, 50 GB for double-layer discs,<ref name="bdfaq1">{{cite web | url = http://www.blu-ray.com/faq/#bluray_capacity_data | title = Blu-ray FAQ: How much data can you fit on a Blu-ray disc? | publisher = blu-ray.com (not affiliated with the Blu-ray Disc Association) | accessdate = 2010-01-09 }}</ref> 100 GB for triple-layer, and 128 GB for quadruple-layer (in BD-R only).<ref name="bd-triple-quad-layers">{{cite web | url = http://www.afterdawn.com/news/article.cfm/2010/06/28/bda_approves_bdxl_quad_layer_blu_ray_standard | title = BDA approves BDXL quad-layer Blu-ray standard | publisher = afterdawn.com | accessdate = 2012-10-15 }}</ref>
The minimum speed at which a Blu-ray Disc can be written is 36 megabits (4.5 megabytes) per second.<ref name="bdfaq2">{{cite web | url = http://www.blu-ray.com/faq/#bluray_speed | title = Blu-ray FAQ: How fast can you read/write data on a Blu-ray disc? | publisher = blu-ray.com (not affiliated with the Blu-ray Disc Association) | accessdate = 2010-06-03 }}</ref>
==Version== There are four versions of [[Blu-ray Disc]] Recordable Erasable (BD-RE) and three versions of Blu-ray Disc Recordable (BD-R). Each version includes three ''Parts'' (a.k.a. ''Books''): Basic Format Specifications, File System Specifications, Audio Visual Basic Specifications. Each part has sub-versions (e.g. R2 Format Specification includes ''Part 3: Audio Visual Basic Specifications Ver.3.02'', ''Part 2: File System Specifications Ver. 1.11'', ''Part 1: Basic Format Specifications Ver. 1.3'').<ref name="r2">{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/r2-spec.php |title=R2 Format Specification |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref><ref name="filesystem">{{Citation |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.com/Assets/Downloadablefile/3_filesystem-15265.pdf |title=White paper – Blu-ray Disc Format, 3. File System Specifications for BD-RE, R, ROM, August 2004 |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref><ref name="bd-books">{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/docs/Spec_Info/AllBooksDec2009.pdf|title=Blu-ray – All Books, As of December 2009 |author=Blu-ray Disc Association}}</ref><ref name="bd-books2010">{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/docs/Spec_Info/Specification%20Book%20Chart.pdf |title=Blu-ray – All Books, As of June 2010 |author=Blu-ray Disc Association}}</ref>
===BD-RE versions=== ====Version 1.0—RE 1.0==== * defined in 2002 * unique BD File System (BDFS) * not computer compatible * BDAV (Blu-ray Disc Audio/Visual) application format<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/re1-spec.php |title=RE1 Format Specification |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> * BDCP as content protection<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/content-protection/content-protection-re1.php |title=RE1 Content Protection |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/content-protection/content-protection-rek1.php |title=RE (Key) 1 Content Protection |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref>
====Version 2.0—RE 2.0==== * defined in 2005 * [[Universal Disk Format|UDF]] 2.5 file system for computer use * the use of [[Advanced Access Content System|AACS]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/content-protection/content-protection-re2.php |title=RE 2 Content Protection |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> * added Hybrid Format—defined for combined discs of BD/CD or BD/DVD. However, BD recording media (BD-RE and BD-R) are inapplicable. This book is attached to "Part 1 Basic Format Specifications" of every format, except BD-RE Version 1.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/hybrid-spec.php |title=Hybrid Format Specification |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> * BD-R Version 1.0 follows this specification<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/re2-spec.php |title=RE2 Format Specification |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref>
====Version 3.0—RE 3.0==== * defined in September 2006 * camcorder (8 cm) discs added—camcorder is added as one of BD product categories * backward compatible with Version 2.0 * added BDMV (Blu-ray Disc Movie) application format<ref name="r2" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/re3-spec.php |title=RE3 Format Specification |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> * BD-R Version 2.0 follows this specification
====Version 4.0—RE 4.0—(BDXL)==== * defined in June 2010 * a multi-layered rewritable in BDAV with the speed of 2× and 4× * capable of 100 GB and usage of UDF 2.5 as file system and Professional Device is a newly added as one of BD product categories<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/re4-spec.php |title=RE4 Format Specification (BDXL) |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-18}}</ref>
===BD-R versions===
====Version 1.0—R 1.0==== * defined in 2005 * [[Universal Disk Format|UDF]] 2.5 file system for computer use * uses [[Advanced Access Content System|AACS]] * BD-R Version 1 Part 3 is the same book as BD-RE Version 2 Part 3<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/r1-spec.php |title=R1 Format Specification |author=Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> * add BD-R Low To High (BD-R LTH) standard.<ref>[http://www.cdrinfo.com/Sections/News/Details.aspx?NewsId=21422 LTH was included in the "Blu-ray Disc Recordable Format Ver.1.2" specifications.] cdrinfo.com</ref>
====Version 2.0—R 2.0==== * defined in September 2006 * camcorder (8 cm) discs added—camcorder is added as one of BD product categories * backward compatible with Version 1 * added BDMV (Blu-ray Disc Movie) application format * BD-R Version 2 Part 3 is the same book as BD-RE Version 3 Part 3<ref name="r2" />
====Version 3.0—R 3.0 (BDXL)==== * defined in June 2010 * a multi-layered recordable in BDAV with 2× and 4× speeds * capable of 100/128 GB and usage of UDF 2.5/2.6 as file system and Professional Device is a newly added as one of BD product categories<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-raydisc.info/format-spec/r3-spec.php |title= R3 Format Specification (BDXL) | author = Blu-ray Disc Association |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref>
==Speed== {| class="wikitable" |- !Drive speed !colspan="3"|Data rate !25GB BD-R(E) write time !50GB BD-R(E) DL (25GB/layer) write time !100GB BR-R(E) XL TL (~33GB/layer) write time |- |1×<ref name="bdfaq1"/>||36 Mbit/s||4.5 MB/s||4.29 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~95 min.||~190 min.||~380 min. |- |2×||72 Mbit/s||9 MB/s||8.58 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~47 min.||~94 min.||~188 min. |- |4×||144 Mbit/s||18 MB/s||17.17 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~24 min.||~48 min.||~96 min. |- |6×||216 Mbit/s||27 MB/s||25.75 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~16 min.||~32 min.||~64 min. |- |8×||288 Mbit/s||36 MB/s||34.33 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~12 min.||~24 min.||~48 min. |- |10×||360 Mbit/s||45 MB/s||42.92 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~10 min.||~20 min.||~40 min. |- |12×||432 Mbit/s||54 MB/s||51.50 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~8 min.||~16 min.||~32 min. |- |14×||504 Mbit/s||63 MB/s||60.08 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~7 min.||~14 min.||~28 min. |- |15×||540 Mbit/s||67.5 MB/s||64.37 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~7 min||~13 min.||~26 min. |- |16×||576 Mbit/s||72 MB/s||68.66 [[Mebibyte|MiB]]/s||~6 min.||~12 min.||~24 min. |}
Note: Add extra time for disc verification phase and time for erasing the disc in the case of BD-RE. == Pricing == {{As of|2013|07}} (approximate pricing) * '''BD-R/RE drive''' [[US$]]50 and above<ref>[http://www.amazon.com/gp/search/ref=sr_nr_n_0?rh=n%3A172282%2Ck%3ABlu-ray+Burners%2Cn%3A%21493964%2Cn%3A541966&bbn=493964&keywords=Blu-ray+Burners&ie=UTF8&qid=1337211906&rnid=493964 Electronics, Computers & Accessories, Blu-ray Burners]. Amazon. Retrieved on 2012-05-16.</ref> {{As of|2014|02}} (approximate pricing)
* '''6× single-layer BD-R disc''' (25 [[gigabyte|GB]]) [[United States dollar|US$]]0.40 each in quantity;<ref>[http://www.amazon.com/PlexDisc-633-814-Blu-ray-Recordable-50-Disc/dp/B00IK46BJC]. Amazon. Retrieved on 2014-07-16.</ref> * '''6× double-layer BD-R disc''' (50 [[gigabyte|GB]]) [[United States dollar|US$]]2.40 in quantity;<ref>[http://www.amazon.com/Smart-Buy-Blu-ray-Recordable-50-discs/dp/B00KB53TF2/ref=sr_1_6?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1408475109&sr=1-6&keywords=bd-r+disc Smart Buy 50 Pack Bd-r Dl 50gb 6x Blu-ray Double Layer Recordable Disc Blank Logo Data Video Media 50-discs Spindle...]. Amazon. Retrieved on 2014-08-19.</ref> * '''2× single-layer BD-RE disc''' (25 [[gigabyte|GB]]) [[United States dollar|US$]]1.60 in quantity;<ref>[http://www.amazon.com/Sony-Bluray-Rewritable-Version-Printable/dp/B00DRFCNZ0/ 25 Sony Bluray Rewritable Disk Bd-re 25gb Blu Ray Made in Japan Version Printable]. Amazon. Retrieved on 2014-02-04.</ref> * '''2× double-layer BD-RE disc''' (50 [[gigabyte|GB]]) [[United States dollar|US$]]4.57 in quantity;<ref>[http://www.amazon.com/Blu-ray-TDK-Recording-Two-layer-Atbev-50hcpwa10z/dp/B0088VGQVA/ Blu-ray Disc for TDK Lor Recording One to 2x Super-硬 Series Bd-re Dl (Two-layer Disk of Long Time) 50gb Atbev-50hcpwa10z (Japan Import)]. Amazon. Retrieved on 2014-02-04.</ref>
{{As of|2014|02}} (approximate pricing) *'''4x BD-R XL disc''' (100 [[gigabyte|GB]]) [[United States dollar|US$]]45 each;<ref>[http://www.google.com/shopping/product/9343646801684357888?hl=en&sclient=psy-ab&q=bd-r+xl&oq=bd-r+xl&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_qf.&bvm=bv.48705608,d.ZWU&biw=2304&bih=1281&tch=1&ech=1&psi=31vhUbPsCci5O_TlgbAE.1373723615957.7&sa=X&ei=_FvhUbD0FozqOKqhgNgC&ved=0CH0Q8wIwAQ Verbatim BD-R XL - 4x 100 GB]. Google Shopping. Retrieved on 2014-02-08.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazon.com/DIGISTOR-Recordable-Printable-Compatible-Required/dp/B00806O390/ DIGISTOR 100GB 4X Blu-ray Disc Recordable BD-R XL Blank Media, White Inkjet Printable Surface]. Amazon. Retrieved on 2014-03-26.</ref> As of June 2016 (approximate pricing) * '''4x BD-R XL disc''' (100 [[Gigabyte|GB]]) [[United States dollar|US$]]22 each;<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.google.com/shopping/product/9343646801684357888?hl=en&sclient=psy-ab&q=bd-r+xl&oq=bd-r+xl&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_qf.&bvm=bv.48705608,d.ZWU&biw=2304&bih=1281&tch=1&ech=1&psi=31vhUbPsCci5O_TlgbAE.1373723615957.7&sa=X&ei=_FvhUbD0FozqOKqhgNgC&ved=0CH0Q8wIwAQ|title=Verbatim BD-R XL - 4x 100 GB|website=www.google.com|access-date=2016-06-17}}</ref>
==BD-R LTH (low to high)== '''BD-R LTH''' is a write-once Blu-ray Disc format that features an organic dye recording layer. "Low To High" refers to the reflectivity changing from low to high during the burning process, which is the opposite of normal.{{vague|date=November 2015}} The advantage of BD-R LTH is it can protect a manufacturer's investment in [[DVD-R]]/[[CD-R]] manufacturing equipment.{{why|date=November 2015}} The manufacturer need only modify current equipment; it need not invest in new production lines.{{cn|date=November 2015}}{{what|date=June 2016}} This is expected to lower the cost of disc manufacturing.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.cdrinfo.com/Sections/News/Details.aspx?NewsId=21422 | title = Pioneer and Mitsubishi Develop Low cost BD-R Discs Using Organic Recording Layers | publisher = CDR info}}.</ref>
Old Blu-ray players and recorders cannot utilize BD-R LTH; however, a firmware upgrade can enable devices to access BD-R LTH. [[Panasonic]] released such a firmware update in November 2007 for its DMR-BW200, DMR-BR100 and MR-BW900/BW800/BW700 models.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.cdrinfo.com/Sections/News/Details.aspx?NewsId=21913 | title = Firmware Adds Support for LTH BD-R Discs to Panasonic Recorders | publisher = CDR info}}.</ref> Pioneer was expected to ship the first LTH BD drives in Spring 2008.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.cdrinfo.com/Sections/News/Details.aspx?NewsId=22521 | title = Taiyo Yuden, Mitsubishi and Maxell Release First LTH BD-R Discs | publisher = CDR info}}.</ref> Sony upgraded the [[PlayStation 3]] firmware enabling BD-R LTH reading in March, 2008.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.afterdawn.com/news/archive/13371.cfm | title = PS3 firmware update v2.20 available – added support for LTH BD-R | publisher = After Dawn}}.</ref>
In 2011, France's Ministry of Culture and Communication conducted a study on the suitability of data archival of LTH (low to high) discs compared to HTL (high to low) discs. The data they collected indicated that the overall quality of LTH discs is worse than HTL discs.<ref>[http://www.myce.com/news/french-research-avoid-blu-ray-lth-discs-for-data-archival-64265/ French research: Avoid Blu-ray LTH discs for data archival]. myce. Retrieved on 2013-06-14.</ref><ref>[http://www.archivesdefrance.culture.gouv.fr/static/6187 Qualite des Disques Blu-Ray Enregistrables pour L’Archivage des Donnees Numeriques]. Ministère de la Culture et de la Communica. Retrieved on 2013-06-14.</ref>
